#### Section 1: Introduction
When solidified by evaporation of a solvent (e.g., paint) or by cooling
from a molten goo, polymers---*plastics*---form a wide variety of useful
objects. In fact, in an indoor environment, many objects are either made
of or coated with a polymer. These plastic objects and coatings have
properties which derive from their molecular structures but which are
also determined by how those molecular structures pack in the solid
state. For example, is the object mostly crystalline? Totally amorphous?
Or somewhere in between? These details determine the thermal stability
and mechanical response of plastic objects in profound ways, as
discussed here. For a video primer to this chapter, visit

>>>video(https://youtu.be/JlasquVHyZ4)

In the last chapter, we explored the synthesis of polymers, starting
with basic organic building blocks, and ways to characterize their
properties in solution. Indeed, polymers in solution are central to many
of the most modern, high-value and technologically sophisticated
products of nanoengineering. For example, lipid nanoparticles
incorporated with polymers like poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) are the basis
of the delivery vehicles for mRNA-based vaccines against COVID-19.
Polymers in solution also comprise **photoresists** used in
microelectronics manufacturing, paint and dye formulations, anticancer
therapeutics that evade immune detection and target cancer cells, and
materials used in hydraulic fracturing in the recovery of natural gas.
However, the vast majority of polymers are used to form solids, which
have distinctive properties owing to their highly **entangled**
microstructure. Such properties include high tensile strength relative
to weight, mechanical toughness, heat resistance, and **thermosetting**
and **thermoplastic** properties, which allow polymeric materials to be
formed into complex 3D objects much more easily than can be ceramics or
metals. In this chapter, we explore how the molecular structure of a
polymer influences its morphology and properties in the solid state.

#### Van der Waals solids

A bowl of sugar (sucrose) is made up of many fine crystals. These
crystals are highly ordered and have a repeating structure which
continues in all directions. Such a crystal diffracts X-rays (**Bragg
diffraction**) from which its structure and the spacing between all its
atoms can be determined. The individual sucrose molecules are held
together by van der Waals forces, including hydrogen bonds, and the
structure is thus known as a **van der Waals solid**.[^6.1.1] Owing to its
unique bonding arrangement, a polymeric solid has some properties of a
covalent solid and some properties of a van der Waals solid. For
example, the monomer residues within a chain are bonded covalently,
while the monomers associate with each other through space by van der
Waals interactions.

#### Polymers: A special class of van der Waals solids

A polymer can be solidified in one of two ways: (1) cooling from the
melt or (2) precipitation of solid polymer from solution upon
evaporation of the solvent. As a polymer solidifies, many different
types of structures can form. These structures depend on the molecular
structure of the polymer, and the thermodynamics and kinetics of
solidification. In general, a polymer forms **crystalline phases** and
**amorphous phases**, with significant polymorphism possible (see Figure
(6.1)).[^6.1.2] Thus, different samples of the same material can have
differences in density in the amorphous phases and crystal structure in
either phase. Crystalline phases are characterized by the **melting
temperature**, $T_m$, while amorphous phases are characterized by the
**glass-transition temperature**, $T_g$.

(Figure 6.1) 
>>>image(phases.png.0)

### 6.1.1. The crystalline phase

Crystalline phases of polymers have regular repeating structures. The
presence of crystalline phases can be determined definitively by
diffraction of X-ray radiation (see Chapter 14). Such a structure is
only possible for polymers that have a regular molecular structure; any
randomness tends to destroy the potential for crystallinity. An example
of a polymer which has multiple **stereoisomers**[^6.1.3] is polypropylene,
which can exist in three basic isomers: **isotactic**, **syndiotactic**,
and **atactic** (Figure (6.2)).

(Figure 6.2) 
>>>image(tacticity.png.0)

Of the three stereoisomers of polypropylene, only isotactic (all methyl
groups oriented the same way) and syndiotactc (methyl groups alternate
orientations) can crystallize. Atactic molecules have random
orientations of the methyl groups and thus cannot pack efficiently
enough to crystallize. In practice, only isotactic and syndiotactic
polypropylene are usable as solid materials, which can be used in
packaging material, textiles (especially carpeting), and consumer
electronic devices; atactic polypropylene is a gummy material used as
adhesives, sealants, and as components of asphalt. However, atactic
chains can be combined by physical mixing or copolymerization with
isotactic or syndiotactic material to tune the mechanical properties
toward being softer.

When we say that a polymeric solid is crystalline, we are typically only
ever talking about 30-80% crystalline. Such a sample is technically
termed **semicrystalline**. The reasons that a polymeric solid cannot be
completely crystalline is because the ability of adjacent molecules to
line up, end-to-end, with each other *exactly* cannot be guaranteed;
moreover, it is statistically nearly impossible, even for a completely
monodisperse sample (= 1.00000). Any dispersity whatsoever creates
non-overlapping chain ends and regions of **free volume** due to
inefficient packing, decreased density, and increased mobility of
chains. At least locally, such a region will not be crystalline.

Crystalline regions of a polymer undergo a first-order phase transition
at a specific temperature, $T_m$. The behavior of the solid observed at
this temperature is exactly analogous to what is observed in metallic,
ionic, or van der Waals solids. That is, the material fairly abruptly
goes from a solid to a liquid, with concomitant changes in **density**
(usually decreases[^6.1.4]) and **heat capacity** (increases[^6.1.5]).
Macroscopically, the polymer melt will not be a free-flowing liquid.
Rather, it will be a **viscoelastic liquid**, meaning that one may still
observe some elastic rebound if it is poked. This **viscoelastic
behavior** occurs because of the timescales needed to translate polymer
chains. It literally takes on the orders of seconds, minutes, or
hours---i.e., "human" timescales---for melted polymer chains to
reorganize themselves in response to a load.

There are many types of crystalline phases possible in a polymer sample.
For example, stretching or shearing a polymer during solidification or
from the melt often produces highly **anisotropic**[^6.1.6] structures in
which the molecules line up along the stretched axis in a crystalline
morphology. Such a structure is produced by the *nylon rope trick*[^6.1.7]
and is often called a shish-kebab because of the formation of roughly
cylindrical nodules along the stretched axis. Other highly anisotropic
structures, nanofibers, nanowires, dendritic crystals, and
"shish-kebabs,"[^6.1.8] see Figure (6.3).

(Figure 6.3) 
>>>image(crystals.png.0)

The canonical crystalline structure for most reasonably flexible polymer
chains---i.e., most polyolefins---is the **spherulite**, as illustrated
in Figure (6.4). A spherulite resembles a three-dimensional snowflake.
It is a hyperbranched structure that nucleates and then propagates in
all directions, continually branching all the way. Despite its name, the
spherulite is rarely spherical, simply because nearby spherulites
impinge on each other and limit their growth. Picture blowing soap
bubbles using a children's bubble wand. Occassionally, some bubbles will
come out as a blob of bubbles, none of which are completely spherical.
Moreover, in confined geometries like thin films, the growth of the
spherulite in the z-axis is constrained, and thus the spherulite grows
in two dimensions only. The presence of these structures can be easily
identified by optical microscopy under cross-polarization.[^6.1.9] The image
one sees is called a **Maltese cross**.

(Figure 6.4) 
>>>image(spherulite.png.0)

For flexible polymers like polyolefins, the crystalline branches of the
spherulite have a **switchboard structure**, in which the chains loop
into and out of a plane which is perpendicular to the molecular axes of
the polymer (Figure (6.4)). The entry and exit into the crystalline
region can be adjacent or random. In the regions in between the
crystalline branches, the polymer is amorphous. The spherulitic
structure---even for the most ordered, crystalline polymers---guarantees
that there will be amorphous material in the polymer solid.

#### Nucleation and growth

Upon cooling of a polymer melt or solidification of a solid from
solution, spherulties grow following a common pattern. The process of
nucleation and growth is illustrated in Figure (6.5). First, polymer
crystallites are seeded in a process called **nucleation**. In this
process, the presence of defects or random variations in density cause
the association of two or more segments of nearby polymer chains (or
different segments of the same polymer chain). The favorable enthalpy of
this type of association causes other nearby chains to be recruited to
the growing spherulite. These structures, which start out spherically
shaped, ultimately impinge upon each other. The ultimate structures are
seldom spherical---the boundaries of the spherulites within the solid
structure end up resembling a blob of soap bubbles.

(Figure 6.5) 
>>>image(nucleation growth.png.0)

### 6.1.2. The amorphous phase

The only phase that one is guaranteed to find in a polymeric solid is
the amorphous phase. Amorphous material is less dense than crystalline
material, and tends to look like a 3D network of cooked spaghetti. The
amorphous phase is characterized by its $T_g$, the temperature at which
the activation barrier for the translation of polymer chains sliding
past each other has been reached.[^6.1.10] Below the $T_g$, the polymer
sample is said to be **glassy**, like cooked spaghetti that is then
frozen in its tangled up state. In this arrangement, mechanical energy
tends to be dissipated by the breakage of covalent bonds, though it can
be made to absorb energy though one or more **sub-$T_g$ relaxation
mechanisms**, which are basically bonds (often side chains) that can
rotate. Such routing of mechanical energy can prevent catastrophic
failure. Above the $T_g$, the polymer is in a state where the molecules
are more or less free flowing in a melt. The glass transition usually
occurs over a small range of temperatures, and one does not get a
discontinuous change in properties such as density or heat capacity.
Instead, these quantities increase gradually.

The diagram below (Figure (6.6)) shows a useful relationship between the
van der Waals volume, the free volume, and the expansion volume (which
accelerates after passing $T_g$) as a function of temperature. The van
der Waals volume is the space taken up by the electron clouds using the
van der Waals radii, $r$ $_{VDW}$ , of all the atoms. The free volume is
the "empty space" between the atoms due to inefficient packing. The
expansion volume is the volume that is dependent on temperature, and
increases with increasing molecular motion. This is the thermal
expansion that makes an exterior door or window more difficult to open
and close when the sun has been shining on it all day.

(Figure 6.6) 
>>>image(free volume.png.0)

#### Factors affecting $T_g$

The glass transition temperature is a quantity that engineers often want
to tune. The reason is that the $T_g$ strongly determines many
thermomechanical properties of interest, including elastic modulus,
strength, and toughness. The $T_g$ depends first and foremost on the
**free volume**. The greater the free volume, the lower the integrated
van der Waals forces between atoms and the easier it is to put the
chains in a state of flow. In general, a monodisperse, pure sample
**annealed**[^6.1.11] from the melt will maximize the $T_g$. Almost any
modifications made to the polymer structure or by blending the polymer
with additives will increase the disorder, thus also the free volume,
and thence decrease the $T_g$. So, techniques for lowering the $T_g$
include

1.  Introducing randomness into the molecular structure

2.  Decreasing $M_n$ or $M_w$

3.  Increasing the dispersity,

4.  Cooling a melt quickly (thermal history)

5.  Adding a small molecule plasticizer

6.  Not fully removing the solvent

### 6.1.3. Measurement of thermal properties

The thermal transitions in a polymer are most readily measured by a
technique called **differential scanning calorimetry** (DSC). In DSC, a
polymer sample is heated in a small metal dish alongside an empty metal
dish. Small amounts of heat are added to the two dishes with the goal of
maintaining a constant temperature between the sample and the empty
dish. During an exothermic transition (e.g., crystallization), heat is
generated by the sample itself, so less heat needs to be added to the
dish to keep the temperature the same as the empty dish. In the case of
an endothermic transition (e.g., melting), the opposite is true. That
is, it takes additional heat to maintain a steady increase in
temperature. Figure (6.7) below shows what one might observe for a
unidirectional scan from low to high temperature of a semicrystalline
polymer sample initially in a highly glassy state.

(Figure 6.7) 
>>>image(DSC.png.0)

The heat capacity is represented by the overall slope of the line.
Notice the increase in slope of the line in the vicinity of $T_g$, after
which there is an increase in the amount of heat absorbable for a given
increase in temperature.

#### Section 2: Mechanical properties of polymers
The mechanical properties of a polymer are ultimately determined by the
molecular structure, but strongly mediated by the phases present in the
solid at a given temperature. These phases also depend on the thermal
history. For example, a semicrystalline polymer sample below $T_m$ and
$T_g$ will be solid, glassy, and high modulus.[^6.2.1] Above $T_g$ but below
$T_m$, the amorphous domains will be flowing and liquid-like, but the
solid structure will be held together by the crystalline domains, which
are connected to one another by **tie chains** that pass through the
amorphous domains. This is sometimes called the **elastomeric regime**,
because a solid material above its $T_g$ has some of the properties of a
rubber. Above $T_m$, the sample is melted into a viscoelastic liquid.
Eventually, the elasticity goes to zero and the viscosity decreases as
well.

### 6.2.1. Effect of $T_g$ on the mechanical properties

Let's first consider what happens when a glassy amorphous material is
heated. A plot is sketched in Figure (6.8) that shows the mechanical
behavior of atactic polystyrene as a function of temperature.

(Figure 6.8) 
>>>image(leathery.png.0)

The material starts in a glassy state with a modulus of around 1 GPa
(typical of polymer glasses). Around $T_g$, the polymer undergoes a
sharp decrease in modulus through a regime called **leathery**.[^6.2.2]
Next, it transitions to a **rubbery** regime where significant
elasticity is retained (at least with small loads and short timescales),
then some of the elasticity is lost in the **rubbery flow** regime,
followed by the **viscous flow** regime. It is not necessary to memorize
these different regimes, just the general shape of the curve, and what
might be happening to the molecules in the sample.

### 6.2.2. Stress-strain behavior

The typical method used to measure the mechanical properties of polymers
is called a **tensile test** or **pull test**. To do this test, one
mounts a sample with a uniform cross section to a pull tester[^6.2.3] and
measures the force as a function of displacement, i.e., the distanced
stretched. To make sense of the data, it is necessary to divide the
force by the initial cross-sectional dimensions to get the **stress**,
$\sigma$, usually expressed in the same units as pressure. The MKS unit
of stress is Pa (1 Pa = 1 N m$^{-2}$). The displacement is converted to
**strain**, $\epsilon$, specifically **engineering strain**, which is
the fractional increase in length from a starting length, $L_0$, see
Figure (6.9).

(Figure 6.9) 
>>>image(strain definition.png.0)

#### Mechanical figures of merit

Let's consider what happens when you stretch of a semicrystalline
polymer. Not all polymers will behave exactly this way, but it is useful
to consider what happens to a typical polymer (see Figure (6.10)). As
the sample is stretched, from 0 to $\le$ 10% strain, the stress needed
to elongate the sample increases at a constant, linear rate. This rate
of increase is called the **tensile** or **Young's modulus**, $E$, which
is the slope of this line. Since the strain has units of m/m, the
modulus, like the stress, has units of Pa. At a certain point, the
stress is no longer proportional to strain. This occurs at the
**proportionality limit**. As the sample is stretched a tiny bit more,
we reach the **elastic limit** or **yield point**. The area under the
curve between 0 and the proportionality limit is called the **modulus of
resilience**, which has units of energy per unit volume. It is the
amount of energy the material can store prior to plastic flow.
Sometimes, but not always, the stress required to elongate the sample
after the yield point decreases until a **lower yield point** is
reached. Upon further elongation, the polymer then undergoes a period of
**strain hardening** due to alignment of the chains, *vide infra*.[^6.2.4]
The polymer is stretched until its failure point. The area under the
entire stress-strain curve is called the **modulus of toughness**, which
is the mechnical energy absorbable by the entire sample per unit volume
prior to fracture.

(Figure 6.10) 
>>>image(stress-strain.png.0)

#### Origins of elasticity

If the above stress-strain curve was obtained for an elastomer (above
$T_g$ and below $T_m$), then the elasticity can be accounted for by a
phenomenon known as **entropic elasticity**. That is, the act of
stretching tends to align polymer chains along the stretched axis. This
restriction in motion is unfavorable, and there is a restoring force
back to equilibrium in order for the mobile chains of the amorphous
domains to occupy as many statistical microstates as possible
(increasing the entropy). If the material is glassy ($T<T_g$), the
elasticity arises primarily from perturbation of the molecules away from
their equilibrium positions. The restoring force is the result of van
der Waals interactions and the preferred angles and lengths of covalent
bonds.[^6.2.5]

#### Molecular origins of deformation

Why are we talking about bulk properties in a course on nanoengineering?
There are two reasons. The first is that the unique properties of
state-of-the-art nanocomposite materials---think the materials that make
up the body of the Boeing 787 Dreamliner---are nevertheless measured
using classical approaches. The second is that each part of the
stress-strain curve can be attributed to processes occurring on the
nanoscale within the material. For example, in our discussion of the
origin of the elasticity in the range of 0 $\le \epsilon \le$ 10%, we
found that the rubber-like behavior was due to entropic elasticity above
$T_g$ and because of the stiffness of covalent bonds and strength of
short-range intermolecular forces below $T_g$.

As the semicrystalline polymer sample whose tensile properties are
depicted in the figure above is stretched to its yield point, mechanical
energy that was stored up elastically is dissipated by pulling
crystallites apart. During this transition, it is possible that the
stress needed to elongate the sample actually *decreases* until the
**lower yield point**, after which the polymer chains realign and
recrystallize. It is common to observe **birefringence** in highly
stretch-aligned polymers, which means that the absorption or scattering
of light or X-rays is different along the stretched axis than it is
along the transverse (i.e., the other) axis, which undergoes
compression.

As the polymer chains align along the stretched axis, it is common for
the stress needed for further elongation to increase, sometimes
dramatically. This strengthening mechanism occurs naturally in the
production of nylon fibers, which is why it makes such good fishing
lines and fibers for reinforced packing materials. It is also what gives
the polymer Mylar its strength. Mylar, which is known as biaxially
oriented poly(ethylene terephthalate) (BOPET) is stretched along both
the $x$ and $y$ axes and forms a strong 2D sheet.

Ultimately, the stretched polymer cannot absorb any more strain, and
additional mechanical energy is dissipated by fracture. Fracture occurs
in one of two ways, by **scission** (breaking of covalent bonds,
generally forming unpaired---radical---electrons on either side of the
break) or **pullout** (chains sliding past each other to the point where
there is no chain left!). Scission tends to occur upon **brittle
fracture** (common in glassy polymers), whereas pullout occurs upon
**ductile fracture** (common in rubbery polymers).

#### Entanglement

A phenomenon unique to polymers owing to the long lengths of the
individual chains is **entanglement**. Entanglement is a type of
**mechanical bond** which occurs because polymer chains can slide past
each other but not through each other. Entanglement is easy to observe
in a pot of cooked spaghetti with the water drained. Note that it's
difficult to pull just a few strands of spaghetti out of the pot with a
fork; usually, a whole clump of noodles come out all at once. These
strands are stuck to each other by capillary and van der Waals forces,
but also because they are entangled with each other. The greater the
molecular weight of a polymer, the greater the number of entanglements
per chain, and---in general---the greater the modulus, strength, and
viscosity of the melt. Often, there is a change in the slope in a plot
of the values of these properties as a function of molecular weight.
This discontinuity occurs at the **entanglement molecular weight**.

### 6.2.3. Analogy to the deformation of metals

It is perhaps remarkable that the tensile behavior of polymers as they
deform is so similar to that of metals. This similarity is striking
because of the fact that the internal structure of these two classes of
materials---and the nanoscale mechanisms of deformation---is very
different. Imagine a polycrystalline sample of a ductile metal, like
gold. In the initial stages of deformation, the gold undergoes elastic
deformation. Atoms move from their equilibrium positions, but not
permanently. Strong metallic bonds provide the restoring force. As the
metal is stretched to its yield point, mechanical energy is dissipated
by dislocations of atoms within the crystalline grains. These
dislocations permit stretching of the metal sample by **plastic flow**.
Dislocations propagate within grains and between them. The ease of
plastic flow depends on (1) the number of grains and (2) how many
dislocations are already present in the grains. The reason for (1) is
because there is an energetic barrier for dislocations to cross a grain
boundary. The reason for (2) is that there is a certain number of
dislocations that can be accommodated in a grain; adding one dislocation
increases the energy needed to add the next one. When a grain can no
longer accommodate additional dislocations or they cannot traverse the
grain boundaries, the metallic bonds break. Often in metallurgy,
dislocations are introduced intentionally by folding and
hammering---working---the metal. This is called **strain hardening** and
it is the same mechanism responsible for the steep increase in strength
near the point of fracture. When metal, e.g., in a bridge, gets close to
this point, we say it is **fatigued**.

The modulus and strength of a metallic sample is also determined by the
size of the grains. A single-crystal of a metal[^6.2.6] is soft because it
is able to accommodate a lot of dislocations and they do not need to
traverse any grain boundaries. A polycrystalline sample---as in a sample
produced by physical vapor deposition---has many grains of micron size
and probably a lot of dislocations within these grains. Thus, a thin
film of a metal is up to two orders of magnitude stiffer and stronger
than a single crystal. This increase in stiffness and strength with the
reduction of grain size is called the **Hall-Petch effect**, as
dislocations are impeded by the sheer number of grain boundaries.
However, when the grains get too small ($<$ a few nanometers), *the
grains themselves* become mobile in the sample and the deformability of
the sample increases. This phenomenon is called the **inverse Hall-Petch
effect** and is one of many nanoscale phenomena that affect the
properties of macroscopic materials.

#### Section 3: Outlook
In the last two chapters, we tried to give you a primer on the role of
polymers in nanoengineering. In chapter 5, we discussed organic chemical
nomenclature and the building blocks of polymers from a molecular
standpoint. That is, *polymers as molecules*. In this chapter, we
examined the ways that these molecules pack in the solid state, and how
these solid-state properties give rise to the mechanical properties
observed at the macroscopic scale. That is, *polymers as materials*. In
particular, the same polymer structure, e.g., polyvinyl chloride, can
have a wide range of materials properties based on the way in which it
was solidified, how much and for how long the sample was subjected to
thermal treatment, and whether or not there were any additives, e.g.,
plasticizers, used in the manufacturing. This flexibility in properties
makes polymers indispensable plastic material for essentially all of
modern technology, from auto parts, to construction materials, to
electronics packaging[^6.3.1] to nanoparticle drug delivery vehicles. In
Chapter 7, the third and final chapter about polymers, we will discuss
some case studies in advanced active polymers for use in the electronics
industry.

#### Section 1: Introduction
When solidified by evaporation of a solvent (e.g., paint) or by cooling
from a molten goo, polymers---*plastics*---form a wide variety of useful
objects. In fact, in an indoor environment, many objects are either made
of or coated with a polymer. These plastic objects and coatings have
properties which derive from their molecular structures but which are
also determined by how those molecular structures pack in the solid
state. For example, is the object mostly crystalline? Totally amorphous?
Or somewhere in between? These details determine the thermal stability
and mechanical response of plastic objects in profound ways, as
discussed here. For a video primer to this chapter, visit

>>>video(https://youtu.be/JlasquVHyZ4)

In the last chapter, we explored the synthesis of polymers, starting
with basic organic building blocks, and ways to characterize their
properties in solution. Indeed, polymers in solution are central to many
of the most modern, high-value and technologically sophisticated
products of nanoengineering. For example, lipid nanoparticles
incorporated with polymers like poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) are the basis
of the delivery vehicles for mRNA-based vaccines against COVID-19.
Polymers in solution also comprise **photoresists** used in
microelectronics manufacturing, paint and dye formulations, anticancer
therapeutics that evade immune detection and target cancer cells, and
materials used in hydraulic fracturing in the recovery of natural gas.
However, the vast majority of polymers are used to form solids, which
have distinctive properties owing to their highly **entangled**
microstructure. Such properties include high tensile strength relative
to weight, mechanical toughness, heat resistance, and **thermosetting**
and **thermoplastic** properties, which allow polymeric materials to be
formed into complex 3D objects much more easily than can be ceramics or
metals. In this chapter, we explore how the molecular structure of a
polymer influences its morphology and properties in the solid state.

#### Van der Waals solids

A bowl of sugar (sucrose) is made up of many fine crystals. These
crystals are highly ordered and have a repeating structure which
continues in all directions. Such a crystal diffracts X-rays (**Bragg
diffraction**) from which its structure and the spacing between all its
atoms can be determined. The individual sucrose molecules are held
together by van der Waals forces, including hydrogen bonds, and the
structure is thus known as a **van der Waals solid**.[^6.1.1] Owing to its
unique bonding arrangement, a polymeric solid has some properties of a
covalent solid and some properties of a van der Waals solid. For
example, the monomer residues within a chain are bonded covalently,
while the monomers associate with each other through space by van der
Waals interactions.

#### Polymers: A special class of van der Waals solids

A polymer can be solidified in one of two ways: (1) cooling from the
melt or (2) precipitation of solid polymer from solution upon
evaporation of the solvent. As a polymer solidifies, many different

#### Section 1: Introduction
When solidified by evaporation of a solvent (e.g., paint) or by cooling
from a molten goo, polymers---*plastics*---form a wide variety of useful
objects. In fact, in an indoor environment, many objects are either made
of or coated with a polymer. These plastic objects and coatings have
properties which derive from their molecular structures but which are
also determined by how those molecular structures pack in the solid
state. For example, is the object mostly crystalline? Totally amorphous?
Or somewhere in between? These details determine the thermal stability
and mechanical response of plastic objects in profound ways, as
discussed here. For a video primer to this chapter, visit

>>>video(https://youtu.be/JlasquVHyZ4)

In the last chapter, we explored the synthesis of polymers, starting
with basic organic building blocks, and ways to characterize their
properties in solution. Indeed, polymers in solution are central to many
of the most modern, high-value and technologically sophisticated
products of nanoengineering. For example, lipid nanoparticles
incorporated with polymers like poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) are the basis
of the delivery vehicles for mRNA-based vaccines against COVID-19.
Polymers in solution also comprise **photoresists** used in
microelectronics manufacturing, paint and dye formulations, anticancer
therapeutics that evade immune detection and target cancer cells, and
materials used in hydraulic fracturing in the recovery of natural gas.
However, the vast majority of polymers are used to form solids, which
have distinctive properties owing to their highly **entangled**
microstructure. Such properties include high tensile strength relative
to weight, mechanical toughness, heat resistance, and **thermosetting**
and **thermoplastic** properties, which allow polymeric materials to be
formed into complex 3D objects much more easily than can be ceramics or
metals. In this chapter, we explore how the molecular structure of a
polymer influences its morphology and properties in the solid state.

#### Van der Waals solids

A bowl of sugar (sucrose) is made up of many fine crystals. These
crystals are highly ordered and have a repeating structure which
continues in all directions. Such a crystal diffracts X-rays (**Bragg
diffraction**) from which its structure and the spacing between all its
atoms can be determined. The individual sucrose molecules are held
together by van der Waals forces, including hydrogen bonds, and the
structure is thus known as a **van der Waals solid**.[^6.1.1] Owing to its
unique bonding arrangement, a polymeric solid has some properties of a
covalent solid and some properties of a van der Waals solid. For
example, the monomer residues within a chain are bonded covalently,
while the monomers associate with each other through space by van der
Waals interactions.

#### Polymers: A special class of van der Waals solids

A polymer can be solidified in one of two ways: (1) cooling from the
melt or (2) precipitation of solid polymer from solution upon
evaporation of the solvent. As a polymer solidifies, many different
types of structures can form. These structures depend on the molecular
structure of the polymer, and the thermodynamics and kinetics of
solidification. In general, a polymer forms **crystalline phases** and
**amorphous phases**, with significant polymorphism possible (see Figure
(6.1)).[^6.1.2] Thus, different samples of the same material can have
differences in density in the amorphous phases and crystal structure in
either phase. Crystalline phases are characterized by the **melting
temperature**, $T_m$, while amorphous phases are characterized by the
**glass-transition temperature**, $T_g$.

(Figure 6.1)

### 6.1.1. The crystalline phase

Crystalline phases of polymers have regular repeating structures. The
presence of crystalline phases can be determined definitively by
diffraction of X-ray radiation (see Chapter 14). Such a structure is
only possible for polymers that have a regular molecular structure; any
randomness tends to destroy the potential for crystallinity. An example
of a polymer which has multiple **stereoisomers**[^6.1.3] is polypropylene,
which can exist in three basic isomers: **isotactic**, **syndiotactic**,
and **atactic** (Figure (6.2)).

(Figure 6.2) 
>>>image(tacticity.png.0)

Of the three stereoisomers of polypropylene, only isotactic (all methyl
groups oriented the same way) and syndiotactc (methyl groups alternate
orientations) can crystallize. Atactic molecules have random
orientations of the methyl groups and thus cannot pack efficiently
enough to crystallize. In practice, only isotactic and syndiotactic
polypropylene are usable as solid materials, which can be used in
packaging material, textiles (especially carpeting), and consumer
electronic devices; atactic polypropylene is a gummy material used as
adhesives, sealants, and as components of asphalt. However, atactic
chains can be combined by physical mixing or copolymerization with
isotactic or syndiotactic material to tune the mechanical properties
toward being softer.

When we say that a polymeric solid is crystalline, we are typically only
ever talking about 30-80% crystalline. Such a sample is technically
termed **semicrystalline**. The reasons that a polymeric solid cannot be
completely crystalline is because the ability of adjacent molecules to
line up, end-to-end, with each other *exactly* cannot be guaranteed;
moreover, it is statistically nearly impossible, even for a completely
monodisperse sample (= 1.00000). Any dispersity whatsoever creates
non-overlapping chain ends and regions of **free volume** due to
inefficient packing, decreased density, and increased mobility of
chains. At least locally, such a region will not be crystalline.

Crystalline regions of a polymer undergo a first-order phase transition
at a specific temperature, $T_m$. The behavior of the solid observed at
this temperature is exactly analogous to what is observed in metallic,
ionic, or van der Waals solids. That is, the material fairly abruptly
goes from a solid to a liquid, with concomitant changes in **density**
(usually decreases[^6.1.4]) and **heat capacity** (increases[^6.1.5]).
Macroscopically, the polymer melt will not be a free-flowing liquid.
Rather, it will be a **viscoelastic liquid**, meaning that one may still
observe some elastic rebound if it is poked. This **viscoelastic
behavior** occurs because of the timescales needed to translate polymer
chains. It literally takes on the orders of seconds, minutes, or
hours---i.e., "human" timescales---for melted polymer chains to
reorganize themselves in response to a load.

There are many types of crystalline phases possible in a polymer sample.
For example, stretching or shearing a polymer during solidification or
from the melt often produces highly **anisotropic**[^6.1.6] structures in
which the molecules line up along the stretched axis in a crystalline
morphology. Such a structure is produced by the *nylon rope trick*[^6.1.7]
and is often called a shish-kebab because of the formation of roughly
cylindrical nodules along the stretched axis. Other highly anisotropic
structures, nanofibers, nanowires, dendritic crystals, and
"shish-kebabs,"[^6.1.8] see Figure (6.3).

(Figure 6.3) 
>>>image(crystals.png.0)

The canonical crystalline structure for most reasonably flexible polymer
chains---i.e., most polyolefins---is the **spherulite**, as illustrated
in Figure (6.4). A spherulite resembles a three-dimensional snowflake.
It is a hyperbranched structure that nucleates and then propagates in
all directions, continually branching all the way. Despite its name, the
spherulite is rarely spherical, simply because nearby spherulites
impinge on each other and limit their growth. Picture blowing soap
bubbles using a children's bubble wand. Occassionally, some bubbles will
come out as a blob of bubbles, none of which are completely spherical.
Moreover, in confined geometries like thin films, the growth of the
spherulite in the z-axis is constrained, and thus the spherulite grows
in two dimensions only. The presence of these structures can be easily
identified by optical microscopy under cross-polarization.[^6.1.9] The image
one sees is called a **Maltese cross**.

(Figure 6.4) 
>>>image(spherulite.png.0)

For flexible polymers like polyolefins, the crystalline branches of the
spherulite have a **switchboard structure**, in which the chains loop
into and out of a plane which is perpendicular to the molecular axes of
the polymer (Figure (6.4)). The entry and exit into the crystalline
region can be adjacent or random. In the regions in between the
crystalline branches, the polymer is amorphous. The spherulitic
structure---even for the most ordered, crystalline polymers---guarantees
that there will be amorphous material in the polymer solid.

#### Nucleation and growth

Upon cooling of a polymer melt or solidification of a solid from
solution, spherulties grow following a common pattern. The process of
nucleation and growth is illustrated in Figure (6.5). First, polymer
crystallites are seeded in a process called **nucleation**. In this
process, the presence of defects or random variations in density cause
the association of two or more segments of nearby polymer chains (or
different segments of the same polymer chain). The favorable enthalpy of
this type of association causes other nearby chains to be recruited to
the growing spherulite. These structures, which start out spherically
shaped, ultimately impinge upon each other. The ultimate structures are
seldom spherical---the boundaries of the spherulites within the solid
structure end up resembling a blob of soap bubbles.

(Figure 6.5)

### 6.1.2. The amorphous phase

The only phase that one is guaranteed to find in a polymeric solid is
the amorphous phase. Amorphous material is less dense than crystalline
material, and tends to look like a 3D network of cooked spaghetti. The
amorphous phase is characterized by its $T_g$, the temperature at which
the activation barrier for the translation of polymer chains sliding
past each other has been reached.[^6.1.10] Below the $T_g$, the polymer
sample is said to be **glassy**, like cooked spaghetti that is then
frozen in its tangled up state. In this arrangement, mechanical energy
tends to be dissipated by the breakage of covalent bonds, though it can
be made to absorb energy though one or more **sub-$T_g$ relaxation
mechanisms**, which are basically bonds (often side chains) that can
rotate. Such routing of mechanical energy can prevent catastrophic
failure. Above the $T_g$, the polymer is in a state where the molecules
are more or less free flowing in a melt. The glass transition usually
occurs over a small range of temperatures, and one does not get a
discontinuous change in properties such as density or heat capacity.
Instead, these quantities increase gradually.

The diagram below (Figure (6.6)) shows a useful relationship between the
van der Waals volume, the free volume, and the expansion volume (which
accelerates after passing $T_g$) as a function of temperature. The van
der Waals volume is the space taken up by the electron clouds using the
van der Waals radii, $r$ $_{VDW}$ , of all the atoms. The free volume is
the "empty space" between the atoms due to inefficient packing. The
expansion volume is the volume that is dependent on temperature, and
increases with increasing molecular motion. This is the thermal
expansion that makes an exterior door or window more difficult to open
and close when the sun has been shining on it all day.

(Figure 6.6)

#### Factors affecting $T_g$

The glass transition temperature is a quantity that engineers often want
to tune. The reason is that the $T_g$ strongly determines many
thermomechanical properties of interest, including elastic modulus,
strength, and toughness. The $T_g$ depends first and foremost on the
**free volume**. The greater the free volume, the lower the integrated
van der Waals forces between atoms and the easier it is to put the
chains in a state of flow. In general, a monodisperse, pure sample
**annealed**[^6.1.11] from the melt will maximize the $T_g$. Almost any
modifications made to the polymer structure or by blending the polymer
with additives will increase the disorder, thus also the free volume,
and thence decrease the $T_g$. So, techniques for lowering the $T_g$
include

1.  Introducing randomness into the molecular structure

2.  Decreasing $M_n$ or $M_w$

3.  Increasing the dispersity,

4.  Cooling a melt quickly (thermal history)

5.  Adding a small molecule plasticizer

6.  Not fully removing the solvent

### 6.1.3. Measurement of thermal properties

The thermal transitions in a polymer are most readily measured by a
technique called **differential scanning calorimetry** (DSC). In DSC, a
polymer sample is heated in a small metal dish alongside an empty metal
dish. Small amounts of heat are added to the two dishes with the goal of
maintaining a constant temperature between the sample and the empty
dish. During an exothermic transition (e.g., crystallization), heat is
generated by the sample itself, so less heat needs to be added to the
dish to keep the temperature the same as the empty dish. In the case of
an endothermic transition (e.g., melting), the opposite is true. That
is, it takes additional heat to maintain a steady increase in
temperature. Figure (6.7) below shows what one might observe for a
unidirectional scan from low to high temperature of a semicrystalline
polymer sample initially in a highly glassy state.
